Name: Inductive Reasoning - PE
Text: The user starts by focusing on Quarterly_Report.docx in Word but then switches to Document1.docx. There's typing and saving here. Then they switch to Chrome for Email - Inbox, open an email about Annual Meeting, reply, send it. Next, switch to Adobe Acrobat for Report_Draft.pdf, scroll, highlight. After that, Excel for Budget_2024.xlsx with updates, then back to Word Document1.docx again, add a reference, save and close. Finally, return to Quarterly_Report.docx, type executive summary, save, and close.

Name: Pattern Recognition - PE
Text: Looking at the log: The first entries in Word are at 08:59:50 for Quarterly_Report, but immediately switch to Document1.docx. Then after working on that document until 09:01:45, they switch to email. The work on Email happens from 09:02 till 09:03:20 when the email is sent. Then switching to Acrobat at 9:04 for Report_Draft.pdf, scroll and highlight. After that, Excel budget file editing starts around 05:00. Then back to Document1.docx again later, followed by Quarterly_Report.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: So possible cases: Case ID could be based on the document or task they're working on. Each time a new document is opened or focused might indicate a new case, but sometimes switching between tasks (like after handling email, going to Acrobat).

Name: Abductive Reasoning - PE
Text: Alternatively, perhaps each distinct file they interact with could be a different case. For example: Case 1: Document1.docx editing session Case 2: Email handling related to Annual Meeting Case 3: Reviewing Report_Draft.pdf Case 4: Budget_2024.xlsx updates Case 5: Quarterly_Report.docx edits

Name: Validation - NE
Text: But wait, the user goes back to Document1.docx after working on Excel. So that might be part of the same case if it's related. Or maybe different cases depending on the time and context.

Name: Backtracking - IND
Text: Alternatively, perhaps each continuous interaction with a document or task is considered a separate case unless interrupted by other tasks. For example: First, they work on Quarterly_Report but switch to Document1.docx for editing (save), then email handling, which might be Case 2. Then Review PDF as Case3, Budget Excel as Case4, back to Doc1 again, then finally Quarterly.

Name: Heuristic Reasoning - PE
Text: In process mining, usually, each case is a separate instance of processing. So even if the user revisits the same document but has a different sequence (after handling other tasks), it's considered another instance.

Name: Deductive Reasoning - PE
Text: But given ambiguity, perhaps safer to split into separate cases when there is a clear switch away for another significant task (like handling email or editing Excel), then return.
